metadata.titleEn: A GNSS-based snow depth data set over northern China (GSnow-CHINA v1.0, 12h/24h, 2013-2022)
metadata.description: The GSnow-CHINA Version 1.0 data set is a long-term snow depth data set developed using observations from the two GNSS networks constructed by the China Meteorological Administration (CMA) and the China Earthquake Administration (CEA). We proposed a comprehensive framework using raw data of the complex GNSS station networks to automatically retrieve snow depth and control its quality. The data set includes snow depth of 24-hour, 12-hour, and 2-hour temporal resolutions if possible, for 80 sites from 2013 ~ 2022 over northern China (25° ~ 55° N, 70° ~ 140° E). The spatial footprint of the data set (i.e., ~1000m2) is distinguished from the current point-scale in-situ data or coarse-gridded data, which can be used as an independent data source for validation purposes. The data set is also useful for regional climate research and other meteorological and hydrological applications. The algorithm and the data files will be maintained and updated as more years of data become available in the future.
metadata.instructions: The snow depth data is stored in CSV format. The name of the file is "SSSS_YYYY_HHh.txt", where SSSS represnts the site name, YYYY represents the year, and HH represents the temporal resolution. For example, hltl_2019_24h.csv represents the 24-hour snow depth file for site hltl in the year 2019.

background: Snow cover is one of the most active elements in the cryosphere, and the maximum snow area during winter nearly occupies 50 % of the total land surface area of the Northern Hemisphere (Frei and Robinson, 1999; Armstrong and Brodzik, 2001; Robinson et al., 1993). The snow change plays a significant role in the hydrological, ecological, and climatic systems (Henderson et al., 2018). Currently, snow cover products derived from optical remote-sensing data present high accuracy (Hao et al., 2021), but snow depth products show significant uncertainties. Snow depth can be measured at point-scale using ground-based ultrasonic snow depth sensors or laser snow depth sensors, and mainly include observations from meteorological stations, snow surveys, and hydrological stations (Kinar and Pomeroy, 2015). Large-scale snow depth can be retrieved from optical, passive microwave (PMW), and active remote-sensing observations (Shi and Dozier, 2000; Guerreiro et al., 2016; Leinss et al., 2014; Che et al., 2016), yet currently operational observations have shortcomings. Optical remote sensing is affected by solar radiation and cloud (Dai et al., 2017). The PMW remote sensing has coarse spatial footprints (>25 km), and the observations saturate in deep snow (>0.8 m) (Lievens et al., 2019). Active microwave remote sensing has a long revisiting period (>20 d) and high cost (Lievens et al., 2019). The available global/hemispheric/regional snow depth data sets are mainly derived from ground observations, microwave remote sensing, model simulations, and reanalysis (Xiao et al., 2020). Previous studies also demonstrated that current snow depth data sets and snow water equivalent data sets show significant inconsistencies and uncertainties, which limit their applications in climate change projections and simulations of hydrological processes (Xiao et al., 2020; Zhang et al., 2021; Shao et al., 2022).
research objective: The two objectives of this study are (1) to propose a comprehensive framework using raw data of the complex GNSS station networks to retrieve snow depth and control its quality automatically; and (2) to produce a long-term snow depth data set over northern China (i.e., GSnow-CHINA v1.0, 12 h or 24 h, 2013–2022) using the proposed framework and historical data from 80 stations.
challenges: However, due to complex environmental and observation conditions, developing robust and operational technology to produce long-term snow depth data sets using observations from various GNSS station networks is still challenging.
methods: The raw GNSS data used for snow depth retrieval are the daily Receiver Independent Exchange Format (RINEX) data derived directly from individual CMA/CEA GNSS sites. The observables for snow depth retrieval, i.e., satellite pseudorandom noise (PRN) numbers, observation time, satellite elevation angle, satellite azimuth angle, pseudorange, carrier phase (CP), and signal-to-noise ratio (SNR), are extracted or calculated from the raw data. The Lomb–Scargle periodogram (LSP) analysis (Lomb, 1976) is executed on several snow-free days to determine the mean reflector heights for each GNSS satellite, each quadrant, and each GNSS frequency. A comprehensive evaluation of the quality of all the GNSS sites is done based on the data quality of the snow-free surface reflector heights in step (2), and the sites are divided into high-, medium-, and low-quality accordingly. For high- and medium-quality sites, the model for deriving daily reflector height is established, and the raw snow depth for each GNSS satellite, each quadrant, and each GNSS frequency is subsequently calculated as the difference value of the referenced height in step (2) and the height of this step. Several quality-control strategies are used to further improve the quality of the raw snow depth during the previous step, such as considering the penetration depth of soil, considering the vegetation effects, filtering of outliers, adding valid flags such as the standard error (SE) of snow depth and the number of PRNs used to calculate a specific snow depth value. Daily 24 h and sub-daily 12 h snow depths are derived for general high- and medium-quality GNSS sites, and snow depths of finer resolution are additionally derived for several GPS/GLONASS compatible sites. The GSnow-CHINA v1.0 data set is evaluated using the PMW product and the in situ measurements. The advantages and limitations of the produced data set are further analyzed to provide supportive information for future method improvement or data set extension.
dataset: The two objectives of this study are (1) to propose a comprehensive framework using raw data of the complex GNSS station networks to retrieve snow depth and control its quality automatically; and (2) to produce a long-term snow depth data set over northern China (i.e., GSnow-CHINA v1.0, 12 h or 24 h, 2013–2022) using the proposed framework and historical data from 80 stations.
findings: The data set has high internal consistency with regards to different GNSS constellations (mean r=0.98, RMSD =0.99 cm, and nRMSD (snow depth >5 cm) =0.11), different frequency bands (mean r=0.97, RMSD =1.46 cm, and nRMSD (snow depth >5 cm) =0.16), and different GNSS receivers (mean r=0.62). The data set also has high external consistency with the in situ measurements and the passive microwave (PMW) product, with a consistent illustration of the interannual snow depth variability. Additionally, the result show the potential of GNSS to derive hourly snow depth observations for better monitoring of snow disasters. The resulting GSnow-CHINA v1.0 data set is distinguished from the current point-scale in situ data or coarse-gridded data, which can be used as an independent data source for validation purposes. The data set is also useful for regional climate research and other meteorological and hydrological applications.

Verification.Question: Can raw GNSS data be used to automatically retrieve snow depth and control its quality?
Is it possible for GNSS-derived snow depth data to have high consistency with in situ measurements and passive microwave products?

Disjunctive.Question: Is snow depth data collection more effectively achieved using ground-based ultrasonic sensors, laser sensors, or GNSS station networks?

Concept Completion.Question: What data collection method is used to retrieve snow depth in GNSS networks?
What challenges are involved in producing long-term snow depth datasets using GNSS observations?
What are the potential applications of the snow depth dataset over northern China?
Concept Completion.Answer: Validation, regional climate research, meteorological applications, hydrological applications

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a comprehensive framework used to automatically retrieve snow depth data from raw GNSS station network data?
Example.Answer: The proposed framework uses raw GNSS data, such as satellite pseudorandom noise numbers, observation time, satellite elevation angle, satellite azimuth angle, pseudorange, carrier phase, and signal-to-noise ratio, to retrieve snow depth. It involves determining mean reflector heights via Lomb–Scargle periodogram analysis, evaluating site quality, deriving daily reflector heights, and employing quality-control strategies such as considering soil penetration depth and filtering outliers.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced when developing technology for long-term snow depth data collection using GNSS observations?
Example.Answer: A challenge includes dealing with complex environmental and observation conditions that make it difficult to develop robust and operational technology to produce long-term snow depth data sets from various GNSS station networks.

Feature Specification.Question: What characteristics define the feature extraction process for snow depth using GNSS station networks?
Feature Specification.Answer: satellite pseudorandom noise numbers, observation time, satellite elevation angle, satellite azimuth angle, pseudorange, carrier phase, signal-to-noise ratio, mean reflector heights, quality evaluation of GNSS sites, models for deriving daily reflector height

Feature Specification.Question: What are the specific challenges faced in developing long-term snow depth data sets from GNSS observations?
Feature Specification.Answer: robust technology, operational technology, accurate data, various GNSS station networks

Feature Specification.Question: What attributes are essential for evaluating the consistency and reliability of snow depth datasets derived from GNSS data?
Feature Specification.Answer: internal consistency across different GNSS constellations, frequency bands, receivers, external consistency with in situ measurements, passive microwave products, mean correlation, RMSD, nRMSD

Quantification.Question: How many GNSS ground stations are used to collect snow depth data over northern China?
What is the temporal resolution of the snow depth dataset over northern China?
What is the spatial coverage of the GNSS snow depth dataset over northern China?

Definition.Question: What is the significance of using GNSS station networks for snow depth retrieval in meteorological research?
Definition.Answer: Using GNSS station networks for snow depth retrieval is significant because it allows for high temporal resolution data collection, covering a spatial range between ground observations and coarse-gridded data. This method enhances the potential applications of existing GNSS observation networks, providing a new data source for validation and supporting research in meteorological and hydrological fields.

Definition.Question: What challenges are associated with developing robust technology for long-term snow depth data collection using GNSS networks?
Definition.Answer: Challenges in developing robust technology for long-term snow depth data collection using GNSS networks include dealing with complex environmental and observation conditions, ensuring the consistency and accuracy of data across different GNSS constellations, frequency bands, and receivers, and improving operational technology to produce reliable data sets from various GNSS station networks.

Comparison.Question: How does the snow depth data collection method using GNSS station networks compare to optical remote sensing in terms of accuracy and consistency?
Comparison.Answer: Snow depth data collection using GNSS station networks shows high internal consistency with regards to different GNSS constellations, frequency bands, and receivers, and high external consistency with in situ measurements and PMW product. Optical remote sensing, while accurate for snow cover, presents significant uncertainties for snow depth due to solar radiation and cloud effects.

Comparison.Question: In what ways does the GNSS-based snow depth retrieval framework address the limitations of existing passive microwave (PMW) and active microwave remote sensing methods?
Comparison.Answer: The GNSS-based retrieval framework offers higher temporal resolution and consistency, overcoming PMW's coarse spatial footprint and saturation in deep snow, and addressing active microwave remote sensing's long revisiting period and high cost. The GNSS approach thus provides potential for more frequent and cost-effective snow depth monitoring.

Interpretation.Question: What potential data collection techniques could enhance the accuracy and reliability of snow depth measurements in regions with complex environmental conditions?
Interpretation.Answer: The use of raw GNSS data from complex station networks to retrieve snow depth can enhance accuracy by automatically controlling the quality through comprehensive frameworks. Techniques like Lomb–Scargle periodogram analysis and quality-control strategies such as considering soil penetration depth, vegetation effects, and filtering outliers can improve reliability.

Interpretation.Question: How might the integration of different GNSS constellations and frequency bands influence the consistency and coverage of snow depth datasets?
Interpretation.Answer: Integration of different GNSS constellations and frequency bands enhances internal consistency, achieving high correlation and low error margins. It improves coverage by allowing more varied and frequent observations, potentially leading to a more accurate representation of snow depth variability and better monitoring capabilities.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways could the use of automated frameworks in GNSS networks address challenges associated with long-term snow depth data production?
Interpretation.Answer: Automated frameworks allow for the systematic processing of raw GNSS data, addressing challenges by providing consistent methods for data retrieval and quality control. Such frameworks facilitate the production of long-term datasets by standardizing data handling across different stations and environmental conditions, thereby enhancing robustness and operational efficiency.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the underlying reasons that make developing robust technology for producing long-term snow depth data sets using GNSS station networks challenging?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Due to complex environmental and observation conditions, developing robust and operational technology to produce long-term snow depth data sets using observations from various GNSS station networks is still challenging.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why are there significant uncertainties in current snow depth products derived from different remote sensing techniques?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Current snow depth products show significant uncertainties due to the limitations of different remote sensing techniques. Optical remote sensing is affected by solar radiation and cloud cover, passive microwave remote sensing has coarse spatial footprints and saturates in deep snow, and active microwave remote sensing has a long revisiting period and high cost.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the high internal and external consistency of snow depth data sets derived from GNSS constellations?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The high internal consistency is attributed to the agreement across different GNSS constellations, frequency bands, and receivers, while the high external consistency is due to the alignment with in situ measurements and passive microwave products, leading to a consistent illustration of interannual snow depth variability.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential outcomes of developing a robust and operational technology to produce long-term snow depth datasets using observations from various GNSS station networks?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Developing such technology could lead to the creation of high-resolution and consistent snow depth datasets over large regions. This would enhance the accuracy of snow monitoring and forecasting, support regional climate research, and improve applications in meteorology and hydrology. Additionally, it could facilitate better monitoring of snow-related disasters by providing more frequent and reliable observations.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences of using raw GNSS data to retrieve snow depth and control its quality automatically?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using raw GNSS data for snow depth retrieval and quality control can result in a comprehensive framework that provides high internal and external consistency with existing measurements. This approach can produce detailed snow depth datasets with high resolution, which are valuable for independent validation and can support various research and application fields by offering accurate and timely data.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary objectives of developing a comprehensive framework for retrieving snow depth from GNSS station networks?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objectives are to propose a comprehensive framework using raw data from complex GNSS station networks to automatically retrieve snow depth and control its quality, and to produce a long-term snow depth dataset over northern China using this framework and historical data from 80 stations.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to address challenges in producing long-term snow depth datasets using various GNSS station networks?
Goal Orientation.Answer: It is important because developing robust and operational technology to produce long-term snow depth datasets from GNSS station networks faces challenges due to complex environmental and observation conditions.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the significance of producing a snow depth dataset with high internal and external consistency using GNSS observations?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Producing a snow depth dataset with high internal and external consistency is significant because it provides a reliable independent data source for validation, useful for regional climate research and various meteorological and hydrological applications, and highlights the potential of GNSS to derive hourly snow depth observations for better monitoring of snow disasters.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the key steps involved in developing a robust framework using GNSS station networks for retrieving snow depth data?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The process involves using raw GNSS data in the RINEX format to extract observables such as satellite pseudorandom noise numbers, observation time, satellite elevation and azimuth angles, pseudorange, carrier phase, and signal-to-noise ratio. A Lomb–Scargle periodogram analysis is executed on snow-free days to determine mean reflector heights. The quality of GNSS sites is evaluated, and sites are categorized into high-, medium-, and low-quality. For high- and medium-quality sites, a model is established to derive daily reflector height, and raw snow depth is calculated based on the difference between referenced and current heights. Quality-control strategies are employed to improve data quality, including consideration of soil penetration, vegetation effects, and filtering of outliers. Daily and sub-daily snow depths are then derived for these sites.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How does the proposed data collection method address the challenges associated with environmental and observational complexities in GNSS networks?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The proposed method addresses these challenges by automatically controlling the quality of snow depth retrievals from complex GNSS station networks. It involves a comprehensive evaluation of GNSS data quality, categorizing sites based on data quality, and applying various quality-control measures to manage environmental and observational complexities. This includes considering soil penetration depth and vegetation effects, filtering outliers, and adding valid flags, such as the standard error and number of PRNs used, to ensure high-quality data output.

Enablement.Question: What data collection methods enable the estimation of snow depth using GNSS station networks in northern China?
Enablement.Answer: The data collection methods involve using daily Receiver Independent Exchange Format (RINEX) data from GNSS sites, extracting observables like satellite pseudorandom noise numbers, observation time, satellite elevation and azimuth angles, pseudorange, carrier phase, and signal-to-noise ratio. The Lomb–Scargle periodogram analysis is used to determine mean reflector heights for snow depth estimation.

Enablement.Question: How does the utilization of GNSS data enhance the accuracy of snow depth measurements compared to traditional methods?
Enablement.Answer: The utilization of GNSS data enhances accuracy by providing high internal consistency across different GNSS constellations, frequency bands, and receivers, and offers high external consistency with in situ measurements and passive microwave products. This method allows for capturing interannual snow depth variability more accurately than traditional methods.

Enablement.Question: What challenges must be addressed to further develop robust technologies for snow depth data collection using GNSS networks?
Enablement.Answer: Challenges include dealing with complex environmental and observation conditions, ensuring data quality across various GNSS station networks, and refining quality-control strategies to handle factors like soil penetration depth, vegetation effects, and filtering outliers.

Expectation.Question: What challenges could prevent the development of a robust and operational technology for producing long-term snow depth datasets using observations from various GNSS station networks?
Expectation.Answer: Challenges include complex environmental conditions and diverse observation conditions across GNSS station networks. These factors make it difficult to develop technology that can consistently and accurately produce long-term snow depth datasets. Variations in site quality and the need for comprehensive data quality evaluations further complicate the process.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be significant inconsistencies and uncertainties in current snow depth datasets and snow water equivalent datasets?
Expectation.Answer: Current snow depth and snow water equivalent datasets may show significant inconsistencies and uncertainties due to varying methodologies in data collection and retrieval, limitations in remote sensing technologies, and the inherent challenges in accurately measuring snow depth and water content. These inconsistencies can affect climate change projections and hydrological simulations.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of using GNSS station networks for snow depth retrieval in terms of accuracy and operational challenges?
Judgmental.Answer: Using GNSS station networks for snow depth retrieval is effective because it produces a data set with high internal consistency across different GNSS constellations and frequency bands. However, there are challenges due to complex environmental and observation conditions that need to be addressed to develop robust and operational technology for long-term data set production.

Judgmental.Question: In the context of enhancing snow depth monitoring, how significant is the role of quality control strategies when utilizing GNSS data for dataset creation?
Judgmental.Answer: Quality control strategies are significant in enhancing snow depth monitoring with GNSS data. They involve addressing factors like soil penetration depth, vegetation effects, and filtering outliers, which are crucial for improving the raw snow depth data quality and ensuring reliable dataset creation for applications in meteorology and hydrology.

Assertion.Question: I can't understand how raw GNSS data is transformed into a reliable snow depth estimate over time.
Assertion.Answer: The raw GNSS data used for snow depth retrieval are the daily Receiver Independent Exchange Format (RINEX) data derived directly from individual GNSS sites. The observables such as satellite pseudorandom noise (PRN) numbers, observation time, satellite elevation angle, satellite azimuth angle, pseudorange, carrier phase (CP), and signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) are extracted or calculated from the raw data. A Lomb–Scargle periodogram (LSP) analysis is executed on several snow-free days to determine the mean reflector heights, which is used to calculate snow depth as the difference between referenced height and the height obtained during snow presence.

Assertion.Question: I'm not sure why creating long-term snow depth datasets from GNSS networks poses challenges.
Assertion.Answer: Developing robust and operational technology to produce long-term snow depth datasets using observations from various GNSS station networks is challenging due to complex environmental and observation conditions. The data quality varies significantly, requiring quality-control strategies to ensure accurate snow depth estimation.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how a dataset of snow depth can be both high-resolution and suitable for regional climate applications.
Assertion.Answer: The dataset provides high temporal resolution with 12-hour and 24-hour intervals and a spatial resolution that represents an area of about 1000m² around each station. This makes it suitable for regional climate research and offers a new source for validation purposes, bridging the gap between point-scale in situ data and coarse-gridded datasets.

Request/Directive.Question: Please discuss the challenges in developing robust technology for producing long-term snow depth datasets using GNSS station observations.
Request/Directive.Answer: The challenges in developing robust technology for producing long-term snow depth datasets using GNSS station observations stem from complex environmental and observation conditions. These include ensuring consistency and accuracy in variable weather and terrain conditions, managing the variability of GNSS signals, and handling the diverse range of data quality across different GNSS sites. Additionally, integrating and harmonizing data from different GNSS constellations, frequency bands, and receivers to maintain high internal and external consistency presents significant technical hurdles.
